Efficient Ru(II) catalysts with substituted aniline based ligands were synthesized having chemical formula [Ru(η6-p-cymene)Cl2(L1)] [Ru-1] and [Ru(η6-p-cymene)Cl2(L2)] [Ru-2] (where, L1 = 3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)aniline and L2 = 3,4,5- trimethoxy aniline). The structural features of both the complexes were authenticated by ESI-MS, 1H and 13C NMR, FT-IR, elemental analyses, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. Catalytic performance of both [Ru-1] and [Ru-2] was investigated for conversion of primary amine to secondary amine using alcohols under milder and solvent-free conditions and compared with the reported aniline-based Ru(II)-arene complex [Ru-3]. Among them, [Ru-1] could achieve 100% selectivity towards mono N-alkylated amines with > 99% conversion without formation of any imine derivatives. The results suggested that the lone pair of electrons of benzyl alcohol binds easily to the electron-deficient Ru(II) center of [Ru-1] catalyst making it more effective compared to electron-rich [Ru-2] and [Ru-3] catalysts. The catalytic performance of [Ru-1] demonstrates that it is one of the most active primary amine ligated Ru(II) based catalytic systems for N-alkylation of anilines under milder and solvent-free conditions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ru(II)-arene complexes Amine ligands Catalytic N-alkylation Solvent-free conditions Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Alkylated amines, because of its prominent structural diversity and rich biological properties, are key compounds with a plethora of applications in chemical and pharmaceutical industries [1,2]. Alkylated amines are commonly adopted as bio-active compounds, agriculture chemicals, functionalized materials, fragrances, dyes and polymers, etc. in both bulk and fine chemical industries [3]. In organic synthesis, the value enhancement of primary amines through its transformation into secondary and tertiary amines via N-alkylation, is attributed as one of the most significant reactions [4,5]. Alkylated aliphatic and aromatic amines are crucial compounds towards synthesis of therapeutic drugs like Clobenzorex, Mefenamic acid, Vascor, Osimertinib and Pexidartinib (Fig. 1 ). Typically, N-alkylated amines have been synthesized by SN2 reactions of alkyl halides and reductive amination of carbonyl compounds with amines. The use of expensive and/or toxic reagents with disadvantages of poor atom economy, less selectivity and stoichiometric generation of byproducts make these processes industrially unfeasible, non-eco-friendly and uneconomical. Thus, to overcome the downsides, alternative catalytic methods namely Buchwald-Hartwig [6], Ullmann [7,8], hydroamination [9], hydroaminovinylation [10], and borrowing hydrogen (BH) strategy [11] have been established for getting secondary and tertiary amines which are viable, sustainable, environment friendly and cost effective. Amongst all, BH strategy using alcohols as alkylating agents has been extensively adopted due to easy availability of reactants, higher atom economy and environmental friendliness [12,13]. The typical catalytic cycle (Scheme 1 ) involves transition metal-catalyzed dehydrogenation of alcohol which produces the corresponding aldehyde, that on condensation with amine gives imine. The imine on further reduction by the hydrogenated catalyst yields the final product and regenerated catalyst at the end [13]. In the early 1980s, research groups of Grigg, Murahashi and Watanabe first reported independent pioneering work on N-alkylated amine synthesis using ruthenium and rhodium based homogeneous catalysts [14]. Afterwards, prominent contributions were made by the groups of Williams [13b-c,15], Crabtree [16], Beller [17], Milstein [18], and Fujita [19]. Moreover, chiral catalysts [20], heterogeneous catalysts [21] and biocatalysts [22] have also been utilized for the amination of alcohols. Recently, BH strategy is extensively studied by the researchers for earth-abundant and nonprecious 3d transition metals like Mn [23], Co [24], Fe [25] and Ni [26] as well as noble metals such as silver [27], gold [28], palladium [29], and rhodium [30]. The studies highlight that alcohols exhibit effective catalytic activity for N-alkylation of amines. These BH reactions are more fascinating but suffers from low yield, less selectivity, higher catalyst loading, limited enantioselectivity and higher temperature compare to precious metals [31]. To overcome these problems, the design of more effective and selective catalyst which can work at milder conditions, is the key interest of all the synthetic chemists. Amongst all noble metals, studies have identified less expensive ruthenium and iridium-based complexes especially, Ru-phosphine complexes [32], Ru-half sandwich complexes [33] and Ru-pincer complexes [34] as effective catalysts. However, utilization of high amount of catalyst [33b], strong bases like KOtBu [33h], inert atmosphere [34e], and use of solvent along with longer time duration [33(i,h), 34(f,g)] make these catalysts non-eco-friendly. Also, there are some hidden drawbacks like synthesis of ligands is tedious and difficult in many cases [33f]. For N-alkylation, most of the catalytic systems do not utilize an equivalent ratio of amines and benzyl alcohols and generally use little excess amount of alcohols. The product selectivity has been compared between N-alkylated amine and imine products excluding the excess benzyl alcohol or potential intermediate/side product benzaldehyde [33(d,f,h,i) 34e-g]. On the other hand, primary amine-based Ru(II)-arene complexes are promising candidates for various catalytic reactions like CH activation [35], transfer hydrogenation [36], acceptor less transfer hydrogenation for hydrogen production [37], homocoupling of boronic acid [38], primary amide synthesis from aldehyde [39], quinoline synthesis and alkylation of ketone [40]. However, very few reports are available on solvent free catalytic transformation using primary amine-based Ru(II)-arene complexes. Perhaps, the use of primary amine-based Ru(II)-arene complexes find no mention for N-alkylation of amines using alcohols in literature. In line with our interest to develop efficient catalysts [41], herein we have presented synthesis and characterization of two new primary amine-based Ru(II)-arene complexes, Ru(η6-p-cymene)Cl2(L1) [Ru-1] and Ru(η6-p-cymene)Cl(L2) [Ru-2] [L1= 3,5(trifluoromethyl)aniline and L2= 3,4,5- trimethoxy aniline]. The synthesized complexes are utilized as catalysts in a solvent-free N-alkylation of amine with alcohol using BH strategy. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods RuCl3.xH2O, α-phellandrene, 3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)aniline (L1), and 3,4,5-trimethoxy aniline (L2) were procured from Sigma Aldrich Chemicals. Commercially accessible AR-grade solvents were purchased from Merck for all purposes. Dimeric Ru(II)-arene precursor [{(η6-p-cymene)RuCl2}2] was synthesized and fully characterized according to the established method [42]. Aniline decorated monomeric [Ru(η6-p-cymene)Cl2(Aniline)] [Ru-3] was synthesized following the reported procedure [39] and confirmed with 1H NMR (Fig. S1). The identity and purity of all the compounds were unambiguously established using melting point determination, NMR (1H and 13C), FT-IR and Mass spectrometry. The Bruker Ascend 400 spectrometer was used to record all the 1H & 13C NMR spectra in CDCl3 at ambient conditions with internal standard as tetramethylsilane (TMS). The chemical shifts(δ) are expressed in ppm. NMR splitting is abridged as: s = singlet, d = doublet, t = triplet, hept = heptet, sept = septet and m = multiplet. Melting points were determined on µThermoCal10 device from Analab Scientific Instruments Pvt. Ltd. The FT-IR Bruker spectrometer was used to record all FT-IR spectra in 4000–600 cm−1 frequency range using KBr as standard. ESI-MS spectra in +ve mode were obtained from MicrOTF-Q II mass spectrometer. Single-crystal data was collected using Rigaku XtaLAB mini II Diffractometer and Rigaku Oxford Diffraction Super Nova diffractometer for [Ru-1] and [Ru-2], respectively. HPLC analysis was carried out on a Dionex HPLC-Ultimate 3000 (High Performance Liquid Chromatography) pump, which was used to analyze the products using Dionex Acclaim ® 120 C18 column. GC–MS analysis was performed using GCHewlett Packard 6890 equipped with HP-5 column (30 m length, 0.25 mm internal diameter and 1 μm film thickness) [43]. 2.2 Synthesis of primary amine ligated Ru(II)-arene complexes 2.2.1 Ru(η6-p-cymene)Cl2(L1) [Ru-1] 20 mL methanolic solution of 3,5(bistrifluoro)methylaniline (0.092 g, 0.40 mmol) was mixed with 5 mL solution of Ru(II)-dimer (0.122 g, 0.20 mmol) in CH2Cl2. For the resulting deep red color solution, the stirring at room temperature was continued for 24 h. The filtrate was kept for slow evaporation which produced red crystalline product. Yield: 77%; m.p.: 235.8 °C; FT-IR (cm−1): 3271, 3191[υ(NH)], 3114 [υ(CH)], 2969 [υ(CH)], 1618, 1464 [υ(CC)], 1379 [υ(CF)], 1278 [υ(CN)]; 1H NMR: δ ppm: 7.98 [s, 2H, 2 × CH of C8H5NF6], 7.56 [s, 1H, 1 × CH of C8H5NF6], 5.16 [s, 2H, NH2 of C8H5NF6], 5.50–5.49 [d, 2H, 2 × CH of C6H4], 5.37–5.35 [d, 2H, 2 × CH of C6H4], 2.93–2.91 [sept, 1H, CH (CH3)2], 2.17 [s, 3H, C6H4CH3], 1.30–1.27 [d, 6H, CH(CH3)2]; 13C NMR: δ ppm:132.18–132.95 [q, 2C, 2 × CF3 of C8H5NF6], 122.0–103.94 [CH of C8H5NF6], 127.27 [C(NH2) of C8H5NF6] 147.44 [C(CF3) of C8H5NF6], 79.73–101.23 [C of C6H4], 18.19–30.64 [C of CH (CH3)2, CH3]; ESI-MS: [Ru(η6-p-cymene)(L1)Cl]+: 500.02 (m/z); Anal. Calcd. for C18H19ClF6NRu (%): C, 43.25; H, 3.83; N, 2.80; Found: C, 43.01; H, 3.92; N, 2.85. 2.2.2 [Ru(η6-p-cymene)Cl(L2)] [Ru-2] 20 mL methanolic solution of 3,4,5- trimethoxy aniline (0.073 g, 0.40 mmol) was mixed with 5 mL solution of Ru(II)-dimer (0.122 g, 0.20 mM) in CH2Cl2 and stirred at room temperature for 24 h resulting in orange crystalline product after slow evaporation of mother liquor. Yield: 89%; m.p: 265.5 °C; 1H NMR: δ ppm: 4.97 [s, 2H, NH2 of C9H11NO3], 6.77 [s, 2H, 2 × CH of C9H11NO3], 3.84 [s, 3H, 1 × OCH3 of C9H11NO3], 3.89 [s, 6H, 2 × OCH3 of 9H11NO3], 5.03–5.04 [d, 2H, 2 × CH of C6H4], 5.10–5.11 [d, 2H, 2 × CH of C6H4], 2.74 [sept, 1H, CH (CH3)2], 2.13 [s, 3H, C6H4CH3], 1.20–1.22 [d, 6H, CH (CH3)2]; 13C NMR :δ ppm: 153.64 [m-C(OCH3) of C9H11NO3], 141.42 [p-C(OCH3) of C9H11NO3], 135.42 [C(NH2) of C9H11NO3], 103.28 [CH of C9H11NO3], 56.41–61.05 [C of OCH3], 79.89–97.76 [C of C6H4], 18.73–30.45 [C of CH (CH3)2, CH3]; ESI-MS: [Ru(η6-p-cymene)(L2)Cl]+: 454.07 (m/z).; Anal. Calcd. for C19H27Cl2NO3Ru (%): C, 46.63; H, 5.56; N, 2.86; Found: C, 46.60; H, 5.58; N, 2.83. 2.3 Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD) studies Single-crystal XRD data collection for [Ru-1] was performed on Rigaku XtaLABmini X-ray Diffractometer coupled with Mercury CCD detector at 298(2)K temperature using multi-scan absorption correction method in which graphite monochromated radiation from Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) was utilized using ω scans. The CrysAlisPro (Version 1.171.39.35c) was used for data reduction [44]. The SHELXT-2015 was used for redetermination of space group for the structure and solved using dual space method [45]. The refinement of crystallographic data was carried out by full-matrix least-squares procedures using SHELXL-2015 [46] software through OLEX2 suite [47]. The Single crystal XRD data collection for [Ru-2] was performed using Rigaku Oxford Diffraction Super Nova diffractometer using the micro-focus X-ray source (Cu, λ = 1.54184 Å) and ω/ϕ scans. The cell refinement and data reduction were done using CrysAlis (Version 1.171.37.35) [48]. SHELX-97 [49] was used for structure solution and the structure refinement was done using SHELXL-2014/7 [46]. The H atoms were fixed on their parent atom using HFIX command while the refinement was performed using the riding model. The ORTEP representation of both the complexes is shown in the Fig. 2 . The ellipsoids of CF3 group are large which indicates thermal disorder that can be modelled using a 100 K data. The Table S1 summarizes the crystal refinement data while Tables S2 and S3 summarize the important bond lengths and bond angles. 2.4 Catalytic N-alkylation of aromatic amine via BH strategy For N-alkylation of amine, catalyst (2 mol%, 0.01 mmol), alcohol (0.5 mmol), KOH (0.5 mmol) and a magnetic bar was charged into the 25 mL borosil round bottom flask and was accompanied with the corresponding substrate (aniline, 0.5 mmol). From the reaction mixture, 20 μL aliquot was taken and diluted with HPLC acetonitrile (ACN) followed by the filtration through Whatman filter paper no.1 and then filtered again through nylons filter (0.45 µm) for the HPLC analysis. Afterward, the filtrate was injected into VWD-equipped HPLC. The results were analyzed at the wavelengths of 254 nm, 280 nm and 305 nm. The standard chemicals were used for the comparison of the structures of the products and the GC–MS (Agilent Technologies, GC6890N, MS 5973) analysis was done for the confirmation of the products. The conversion was defined as the molar ratio of the of reactant consumed during reaction with the initial amount of reactant. Therefore, the area ratio of the products in the HPLC chromatogram was defined as selectivity. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and spectral characterization Nitrogen-containing Ru(II)-arene complexes are widely known for its catalytic activities. Among them, primary amine-based Ru(II)-arene complexes are more preferred choice as catalysts as they are easy to prepare with high yield and excellent catalytic activity. Also, the ligands are simple and readily available. However, the N-alkylation of amines with alcohol has not been explored using this type of catalysts. Hence, two new mononuclear Ru(II)-arene complexes, [Ru-1] and [Ru-2] were synthesized by treating L1 and L2 respectively, with [(p-cymene)RuCl2]2 in ratio of 2:1 at RT (Scheme 2 ). Both the complexes were obtained in pure form after the controlled slow evaporation of mother liquor which produced colored crystalline solids with nonhygroscopic property and air stability. They exhibited easy solubility in polar organic solvents (e.g. methanol, DMF, DMSO, etc.) but are partly soluble or insoluble in non-polar solvents. The high yielding complexes were characterized using 1H and 13C NMR, elemental analyses and mass spectrometry (Fig. S2-S8). In [Ru-1], 1H NMR spectrum exhibits two doublets for phenyl protons of p-cymene ring in the range of 5.35–5.50 ppm, whereas similar protons in [Ru-2] resonate at 5.03–5.11 ppm. Also, side-chain protons of p-cymene ring in [Ru-1] (1.27–1.30; 2.17 and 2.93 ppm) are more deshielded compared to [Ru-2] protons of the same (1.20–1.22; 2.13 and 2.74 ppm). This clearly indicates that more electron-rich Ru(II) center is present in [Ru-2] compared to [Ru-1]. Drastic deshielding effect is observed for NH2 protons in case of both the complexes. In [Ru-1] and [Ru-2], two NH2 protons show a broad peak at 5.16 ppm and 4.97 ppm respectively, which is downshifted compared to free L1(∼4.0 ppm) and L2 (∼3.6 ppm) protons. This indicates the binding of amine nitrogen with ruthenium metal center. All the aromatic protons of coordinated L1 and L2 are observed in the range 7.56–7.98 and 6.77 ppm. Two singlets for methoxy protons of L1 in [Ru-2] are obtained at 3.84 and 3.89 ppm. In 13C NMR of [Ru-1], most deshielded carbon [C(CF3)] is observed at 147.44 ppm, other aromatic carbons of Ru(II) coordinated L1 resonates in the range of 127.46–103.94 ppm. Characteristic quadrupole for CF3 carbons are observed in the range of 132.18–132.95 ppm. In 13C NMR of [Ru-2], OCH3 substituted aromatic carbons are most deshielded and observed at 153.64 and 141.42 ppm. Aromatic C(NH2) and CH carbons are observed at 135.42 and 103.28 ppm, respectively. All the phenyl carbons of p-cymene ring are detected in the band of 79.73–101.23 ppm along with its side-chain carbons at 18.19–30.64 ppm. In the FT-IR spectrum of [Ru-1], two spikes appear at 3271 and 3191 cm−1 showing the presence of 1° amine (NH2) group. υ(CN) stretching frequency is observed at 1278 cm−1. The sharp band at 1379 cm−1 indicates the υ(CF) stretching frequency. Also, aromatic ring revealing υ(CC) stretching frequency is obtained at 1618 and 1464 cm−1 as sharp band. The band attributable to υ (CH) and υ(CH) stretching frequency is observed at 3114 and 2969 cm−1, respectively. The ESI-MS peaks for [Ru(η6-p-cymene)(L1)Cl]+ and [Ru(η6-p-cymene)(L2)Cl]+ are obtained at 500.02 and 457.04 (m/z), respectively due to formation of positively charged species after the loss of one labile chloride atom. All spectroscopic evidences are matching well with the proposed structures giving clear indication of the formation of both complexes [35,36a,38,39]. 3.2 Structural identification of [Ru-1] & [Ru-2] by single crystal XRD On controlled slow evaporation of mother liquor, [Ru-1] and [Ru-2] gave block-shaped red and orange crystals, respectively. Both the complexes crystallized in a triclinic P 1 ¯ space group. Wherein, Ru(II) center was coordinated with planer p-cymene moiety in π-bonding fashion and adopted a typical three-legged piano-stool structure with one nitrogen from ligand (L1 or L2) and two chlorides, which gave pseudo octahedral geometry to both the complexes. Because of strong electron-withdrawing effect of (CF3) in [Ru-1], Ru(1)-N(1) bond distance of 2.197 Å was little higher compared to [Ru-2] (2.167 Å) and comparable with reported unsubstituted aniline-based system [Ru-3] (2.180 Å) [35]. This clearly indicated that [Ru-1] has an electron-deficient Ru(II) center compared to [Ru-2]. Distance between Ru(II) and the aromatic carbons of the p-cymene ring varies in the range of 2.169(3) to 2.208(3) Å for [Ru-1] and 2.156(5) to 2.189(5) Å for [Ru-2] with an average Ru(II)-Cg (Centroid of p-cymene ring) distance of 2.184 Å and 2.177 Å for [Ru-1] and [Ru-2], respectively. The bond distance of two labile chlorides around Ru(II) i.e. Ru(1)-Cl(1) and Ru(1)-Cl(2) was obtained at 2.4203(6) and 2.4166(7) Å, respectively for [Ru-1] and 2.4154(12) and 2.4191(11) Å, respectively for [Ru-2]. Bond angles between the legs in [Ru-1] [Cl(2)-Ru(1)-Cl(1): 87.90(3) Å, N(1)-Ru(1)-Cl(1): 82.35(6) Å and N(1)-Ru(1)-Cl(2): 80.65(7) Å] and [Ru-2] [Cl(2)-Ru(1)-Cl(1): 87.33(5) Å, N(1)-Ru(1)-Cl(1): 82.37(12) Å and N(1)-Ru(1)-Cl(2): 80.61(11) Å] were quite similar for both the complexes. The angle between C(1)-N(1)-Ru(1) was found to be 115.40(16) Å for [Ru-1] and similar C(11)-N(1)-Ru(1) angle was found to be 117.2(3) Å for [Ru-2]. The crystallographic data for both the complexes were comparable with reported work [35,36a,38,39]. 3.3 Catalytic N-alkylation of amines by synthesized complexes To analyze the catalytic affinity of synthesized Ru(II)-arene complexes towards the N-alkylation reaction, the catalyst screening was initially done in presence of base (KOH) under neat condition as shown in Table 1 . Under neat condition at 110 °C with 2 mol% of [Ru-1], about 99% conversion of benzyl alcohol was observed with 80% product selectivity to N-benzyl aniline after 6 h but unfortunately, only 32% and 90% conversion was found for [Ru-2] and [Ru-3], respectively (entries 2 and 3, Table 1) under similar conditions. With that, [Ru-1] could achieve 100% selective towards monoalkylated amine product with no imine formation among all possible N-alkylated products. Probably, strong electron-withdrawing nature of CF3 in [Ru-1] enhanced coordinative ability with substrate which plays crucial role in this transformation. Whereas strong electron-donating nature of OMe in [Ru-2], decreased the binding ability with substrate [33c]. To the best of our knowledge, [Ru-1] is found to be the most active primary amine ligated Ru(II) based catalytic system for N-alkylation of anilines [41a]. A further, detailed catalytic study was carried out using only [Ru-1]. The activity decreased upon further reduction in the amount of catalyst (entries 4–6, Table 1). The neat condition was found to be superior to other solvent conditions after screening. Low boiling solvents such as ACN, THF and DCM underperformed likely due to insufficient temperature, while very low conversion was observed in the case of water due to substrate immiscibility. Additionally, moderate conversion was observed for DMF and Toluene (entries 7–12, Table 1). Further, changing the base from KOH to other bases like NaOH or Na2CO3 resulted in substrate conversion of 82% and 85% respectively, while the selectivity towards N-benzylaniline (entries 5 and 6, Table 2 ) remained at 80%. In presence of K2CO3 and Cs2CO3, only 68% and 70% conversion was observed, respectively (entries 7 and 8, Table 2). However, conversion of the substrates could not be identified in absence of the catalyst. Further, no catalytic reaction occurred at room temperature or in absence of base. After screening solvent, base and catalyst amount, the effect of substitution on benzyl alcohol was studied in N-alkylation reactions with aniline (entries 2–6, Table 3 ). Substituting halide or methyl groups at the para position of benzyl alcohol results in similar conversion and good selectivity up to 84%, with p-Cl exhibiting the highest selectivity. The strong electron-donating nature of p-OMe makes the corresponding aldehyde less electrophilic and thus less likely to react with aniline, resulting in lower conversion rates. The presence of strong electron-withdrawing p-NO2 substitution on benzyl alcohol reduces its binding affinity with the catalyst, resulting in lower conversion (entry 6, Table 3). Substituted anilines were utilized for further substrate scope (entries 1–4, Table 4 ) in which the highest yield was obtained with methyl-substituted aniline, while anilines with strong electron-withdrawing groups led to very low selectivity for the N-alkylated product, likely due to their reduced nucleophilicity. These results suggest that increasing the electron density on benzene ring can enhance the rate of reaction. p-Me substituted benzyl alcohol in combination with various anilines (entries 1–5, Table 5 ) was examined for N-alkylation. The results indicated that electron-donating substituents on both substrates favoured N-alkylation. In particular, p-Me substitution on both substrates yielded the highest selectivity, with 93% yield. Conversely, anilines with electron-withdrawing groups gave very low or no yield for the desired product. After that, halide-substituted benzyl alcohols with various anilines were examined (entries 5–10, Table 5) and found that p-Cl substitution gave slightly higher selectivity and yield compared to p-Br substitution on Benzyl alcohol. Moreover, product selectivity followed the order of p-Me > p-OMe > p-NO2 substitution on aniline. For p-OMe substituted benzyl alcohol (entries 11–13, Table 5), the use of p-Me substituted aniline achieved 100% selectivity with a decent 70% yield. Further, p-NO2 substituted benzyl alcohol with the combination of electron-donating anilines (entries 14–15, Table 5) was examined. Both p-Me and p-OMe anilines gave 100% selectivity, but with a poor yield of only 30%. Lastly, the N-alkylation of 4-aminopyridine with various benzyl alcohols was investigated (entries 1–6, Table 6 ) and results showed consistency with the previous experimental trend. Halide and methyl substituted benzyl alcohols gave up to 74% yield of desired product, while p-NO2 substituted benzyl alcohol gave very poor yield. In the absence of aniline, benzaldehyde was produced with 100% selectivity under standard conditions (entry 7, Table 6). This result is consistent with the borrowing hydrogen strategy, which is commonly used to convert less electrophilic alcohols into more electrophilic aldehydes/ketones. The literature suggests that the formation of benzaldehyde in this case is only possible through β-hydride elimination of benzyl alcohol intermediate [50]. Therefore, these findings confirm the formation of Ru-H intermediate and support the borrowing hydrogen-based mechanism for the N-alkylation reaction catalyzed by [Ru-1]. Homogeneous catalysts can sometimes be deactivated into nanoparticles under harsh conditions, which can result in a misinterpretation of the reaction mechanism. To accurately determine the true nature of catalysis, it is essential to conduct a poisoning test [51]. In this study, elemental mercury (1–3 equiv. to aniline) was added to the reaction mixture to perform the poisoning test (Scheme 3 ). However, the catalytic performance of the catalyst was not affected by addition of Hg(0), Indicating that the reaction was homogeneous in nature [39a,52]. 3.4 Probable mechanism for catalytic N-alkylation reaction In catalytic N-alkylation via BH methodology, the catalyst plays a crucial role in dehydrogenating the alcohol and transferring hydrogen to the imine intermediate. The transfer hydrogenation to ketone and imine can occur through two approaches according to literature, the classical Schrock-Osborn mechanism (Inner-sphere) and the non-classical Noyori mechanism (Outer-sphere) [53]. In case of outer-sphere mechanism, NH/NH2 functionality is essential which enhances the transfer hydrogenation to ketones [36,53,54]. However, in case of N-alkylation with Nitrogen based Ru(II)-arene complexes without NH/NH2 functionality, the reported literature suggests that traditional inner-sphere mechanistic approach is followed [55,56]. Based on the presence of NH2 functionality, it is expected that [Ru-1] complex follows the outer-sphere mechanism (Scheme 4 ). Initially, the intermediate complex (III) is formed, which produces the respective aldehyde and Ru-H species (IV). The aldehyde then forms a Schiff base with aniline derivatives. The transfer hydrogenation process takes place through the formation of a six-membered transition state (V). Subsequently, the obtained amino complex (VI) undergoes elimination to yield the N-alkylated product. The lone pair of electrons of the benzyl alcohol binds easily to the electron-deficient Ru(II) center in [Ru-1] at the last step of the mechanism and restart the whole process for another cycle. During this catalytic cycle, imine formation was confirmed by GC–MS after 4 h of reaction (Fig. S18) suggesting that the desired amine is obtained via imine intermediate. However, due to consumption of more alcohol as compared to primary amine at the end of reaction, greater number of Ru-H (hydrides) species might have generated compared to imine intermediate leading to complete reduction of imine intermediate into desired product. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have developed and characterized two electronically tuned Ru(II)-arene complexes [Ru-1] and [Ru-2] with primary amine ligands. These complexes were thoroughly characterized using variety of advanced analytical and spectroscopic techniques. The internal lattice structures for both complexes were precisely determined through single-crystal XRD analysis. The catalytic performance of [Ru-1] and [Ru-2] was examined for the N-alkylation of primary amines with benzyl alcohols under solvent-free conditions. Furthermore, the catalytic data of the synthesized complexes were compared with the data of reported unsubstituted aniline based complex [Ru-3]. The results indicated that the substituted aniline ligated complex [Ru-1], which bears an electron-deficient Ru(II) center, exhibited excellent conversion with 100% product selectivity for amines among all possible N-alkylated products whereas 80% selectivity among all products compared to electron-rich [Ru-2] and unsubstituted aniline ligated [Ru-3]. Here, NH2 functionality plays a crucial role during the hydride transfer, which stabilized the intermediate via formation of six-membered transition state. Moreover, electron withdrawing group on aniline in [Ru-1] increased the acidity of NH2 hydrogens that was fully utilized for the formation of active complex (II), which is essential for outer-sphere mechanism. Also, substrate can easily bind with an electron-deficient Ru(II) center of [Ru-1] in the last step of mechanism and restart the whole process for another cycle. At the end, it can be concluded that electron deficient Ru(II) center with NH2 functionality is good for transfer hydrogenation based N-alkylation. The conversion and selectivity for 2° amine as a product were highly altered with the nature of reactants. coredata.dc:description: Efficient Ru(II) catalysts with substituted aniline based ligands were synthesized having chemical formula [Ru(η6-p-cymene)Cl2(L1)] [Ru-1] and [Ru(η6-p-cymene)Cl2(L2)] [Ru-2] (where, L1 = 3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)aniline and L2 = 3,4,5- trimethoxy aniline). The structural features of both the complexes were authenticated by ESI-MS, 1H and 13C NMR, FT-IR, elemental analyses, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. Catalytic performance of both [Ru-1] and [Ru-2] was investigated for conversion of primary amine to secondary amine using alcohols under milder and solvent-free conditions and compared with the reported aniline-based Ru(II)-arene complex [Ru-3]. Among them, [Ru-1] could achieve 100% selectivity towards mono N-alkylated amines with > 99% conversion without formation of any imine derivatives. The results suggested that the lone pair of electrons of benzyl alcohol binds easily to the electron-deficient Ru(II) center of [Ru-1] catalyst making it more effective compared to electron-rich [Ru-2] and [Ru-3] catalysts. The catalytic performance of [Ru-1] demonstrates that it is one of the most active primary amine ligated Ru(II) based catalytic systems for N-alkylation of anilines under milder and solvent-free conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Highly active primary amine ligated Ru(II)-arene complexes as selective catalysts for solvent-free N-alkylation of Anilines
